awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Novel Dual-Pulse Laser Ablation and Plasma Amplification (LAPA) Process for Drilling Non-straight Holes with Arbitrarily Varying Diameters
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funding to study a novel dual-pulse laser ablation and plasma amplification (LAPA) process for drilling non-straight microholes with diameters varying arbitrarily with depth. Such kinds of microholes have been increasingly needed by many important applications. However, their precise and efficient drilling still remains a big challenge. The research objectives are to (1) test the hypothesis that in LAPA the amplification of nanosecond-laser-generated plasma by a second picosecond laser pulse can realize controlled and precise material removal from a microhole sidewall through plasma-sidewall interactions and (2) understand the fundamental physics associated with LAPA. The specific research tasks include: (1) Establish an experimental set-up for LAPA. (2) Establish theoretical models for LAPA, which can simulate laser ablation and plasma generation, and laser-plasma-sidewall interactions. (3) Measure the plasma properties to verify the models and understand the fundamental physical processes in LAPA. (4) Perform a feasibility experimental study under the guidance of the verified models.  The pump-probe, fast imaging and emission spectroscopy techniques will be used in plasma property measurements. The nonlinear Schrödinger equation and two-temperature hydrodynamic equations will be solved and coupled with a molecular dynamics/Monte Carlo module in modeling the laser-plasma-hole sidewall interactions during LAPA.   

LAPA is a novel manufacturing process proposed by the PI.  Its essential physical process is the interaction among picosecond laser pulse, plasma (generated by a prior nanosecond laser pulse), and microhole sidewall, which has been rarely studied and is still poorly understood. This project will provide a good, fundamental understanding of this interaction by combining multiscale modeling with comprehensive experiments. The research work will build a solid scientific foundation crucial for LAPA's practical applications. It will also improve our understanding of laser-plasma-material interactions in the general sense, which may improve other existing or inspire new laser and/or plasma-assisted manufacturing processes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This project involves the study of microhole drilling through dual-pulse laser ablation and the modification of the hole shape using laser-induced plasma–hole interaction to drill non-straight microholes with diameters that vary with depths.

Intellectual Merit

Physics-based computational modeling studies have been performed on the interaction among a short laser pulse, a pre-existing plasma plume in a microhole, and the hole sidewall. Under the studied conditions, it has been found that: (1) the interaction can cause spatially selective material removal (through surface vaporization) from the sidewall surface; (2) a higher initial plasma temperature can cause more material removal from the sidewall; and (3) heat conduction plays a more important role than thermal radiation in removing the material from the sidewall.  

Investigations were also done on dual-pulse laser ablation utilizing laser pulse pairs consisting of a high-energy pulse and a low-energy pulse. Under the investigated conditions, it was found that if the low-energy pulse precedes the high-energy pulse (called “low-high double-pulse” laser ablation) by a suitable amount of time in each laser pulse pair, then the ablation rate per incoming laser energy (in terms of drilling depth) can be enhanced by more than four times than single-pulse laser ablation or “high-low double-pulse” laser ablation, when drilling a microhole completely through a workpiece. Under suitable conditions, the “low-high double-pulse” laser ablation can produce a deep and through microhole in a ~0.93mm-thick aluminum 7075 workpiece with an impressive aspect ratio (ratio of the hole depth to the hole diameter) of at least ~15. On the other hand, the studied double-pulse laser ablation was not able to sufficiently remove material (if any) from the hole sidewall to produce desired hole diameter variations with the depth before the moment of the workpiece perforation, in order to produce a hole whose diameter varies with the depth in a complicated way (e.g., a hole whose diameter first decreases and then increases with the depth). However, if after the workpiece is drilled through, double-pulse laser ablation is performed to generate a plasma plume by ablating a solid backing layer placed behind the workpiece, the plasma–hole interaction can eventually lead to a through microhole whose diameter first decreases and then increases with the hole depth in a carbon steel workpiece.  

 In a short summary, this project has improved our understanding of short-pulsed laser beam–plasma–microhole interactions, double-pulse laser ablation for microhole drilling, and microhole-shape modifications through laser-induced plasma.  

 Broader Impacts

 This study has contributed to the improvement of drilling technologies in producing non-straight microholes with relatively complicated diameter variations with depths (such as a hole whose diameter first decreases and then increases with its depth). Such microholes could be beneficial in important applications or fields.  For example, they are useful in fuel injector nozzles for diesel engines, and may help increase fuel efficiency and decrease emission for the engine [1]. Four graduate students working with Dr. Shin were partially involved in the project.  About six graduate students (including one woman) and one undergraduate student working with Dr. Wu have been involved.

 Reference:

  1. Clarke, J. A., Profeta, J., “Laser micro-drilling applications”, Proceedings of the 2004 Advanced Laser Applications Conference and Exposition, 2004.

Last Modified: 01/12/2017
Modified by: Yung C Shin
